natural problem: What is the smallest integer $k$ such that $k>1$ and $k$ has remainder $1$ when divided by any of $17,$ $6,$ and $2?$
natural solution: We can re-write the problem as the following three equations: $$k = 17a+1\\k = 6b+1 \\ k = 2c + 1$$Therefore, $k-1$ is divisible by $17,$ $6,$ and $2.$ The smallest positive value of $k-1$ is thus $$\text{lcm}[17,6,2] = \text{lcm}[17,6] = 17\cdot 6 = 102,$$and so the smallest possible value of $k$ is $k = 102+1 = \boxed{103}.$

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes k :: int
assumes h0 : "k > 1"
and h1 : "k mod 17 = 1"
and h2 : "k mod 6 = 1"
and h3 : "k mod 2 = 1"
shows  "k = 103"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 What is the smallest integer $k$ such that $k>1$ and $k$ has remainder $1$ when divided by any of $17,$ $6,$ and $2?$ The final Answer is 103
 ### Proof
 We can re-write the problem as the following three equations: $$k = 17a+1\\k = 6b+1 \\ k = 2c + 1$$Therefore, $k-1$ is divisible by $17,$ $6,$ and $2.$ The smallest positive value of $k-1$ is thus $$\text{lcm}[17,6,2] = \text{lcm}[17,6] = 17\cdot 6 = 102,$$and so the smallest possible value of $k$ is $k = 102+1 = \boxed{103}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes k :: int
assumes h0 : "k > 1"
and h1 : "k mod 17 = 1"
and h2 : "k mod 6 = 1"
and h3 : "k mod 2 = 1"
shows  "k = 103"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Find an integer $k$ greater than 1 such that $k$ leaves a remainder of 1 when divided by 17, 6, and 2. The final answer is $k = 103$.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes k :: int
assumes h0 : "k > 1"
and h1 : "k mod 17 = 1"
and h2 : "k mod 6 = 1"
and h3 : "k mod 2 = 1"
and h4 : "\<forall> i \<ge> 2. i < k \<longrightarrow> \<not> (i mod 17 = 1 \<and> i mod 6 = 1 \<and> i mod 2 = 1)"
shows  "k = 103"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 What is the smallest integer $k$ such that $k>1$ and $k$ has remainder $1$ when divided by any of $17,$ $6,$ and $2?$ The final Answer is 103
 ### Proof
 We can re-write the problem as the following three equations: $$k = 17a+1\\k = 6b+1 \\ k = 2c + 1$$Therefore, $k-1$ is divisible by $17,$ $6,$ and $2.$ The smallest positive value of $k-1$ is thus $$\text{lcm}[17,6,2] = \text{lcm}[17,6] = 17\cdot 6 = 102,$$and so the smallest possible value of $k$ is $k = 102+1 = \boxed{103}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes k :: int
assumes h0 : "k > 1"
and h1 : "k mod 17 = 1"
and h2 : "k mod 6 = 1"
and h3 : "k mod 2 = 1"
and h4 : "\<forall> i \<ge> 2. i < k \<longrightarrow> \<not> (i mod 17 = 1 \<and> i mod 6 = 1 \<and> i mod 2 = 1)"
shows  "k = 103"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: Find the smallest integer greater than 1 that leaves a remainder of 1 when divided by 17, 6, and 2. The final answer is 103.
